conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The x-axis represents time (t), ranging from 0 to 3 seconds.
The y-axis represents velocity (v), ranging from -2 m/s to 2 m/s.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
Displacement can be found by calculating the area under the v-t graph.

premise: The area under the curve from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds will give us the total displacement.
conclusion: The area under the curve from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds will give us the total displacement.

premise: From t = 0 to t = 1 second: The area is a rectangle with height 2 m/s and width 1 s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds: The area is a triangle with base 1 s and height 2 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds: The area is a triangle with base 1 s and height 2 m/s.
Total displacement is the sum of the areas calculated.
conclusion: Total Displacement = Area_1 + Area_2 + Area_3 = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4 m

premise: Since the total displacement is 4 meters, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
conclusion: No, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
